from the Museum of printing in Massachusetts does anyone know what this machine
is it's a scanner this machine if you wanted to get a photo into the computer in the
early 1980s you would buy one of these this thing cost about a million dollar
and it scanned photographs you put a color photograph you tape it on you see in the middle of the picture there there's this little spinning drum you
tape your photograph on there and then you switch it on I've actually seen one of these in action once when I was a kid

here and it's the story of the Olympic Games does anyone
know where the Olympics were held in the year 200000 Sy Sydney Sydney Australia now
the Olympic Games is it's a big deal it's also an interesting Watershed because it happens every four years and
four years in Tech is long enough that a lot of things can have changed since the last one but short enough that you can
still draw meaningful comparisons every press organization every newspaper in the world they send reporters and
photographers to cover the Olympics because it's big news if you went to Atlanta Georgia United States 1996 as a
press photographer covering the Olympic Games you shot on film you spent the whole day taking pictures at the end of
the day you would run to the Kodak press Center in the Olympic Village you'd give them all your film they would develop it
for you as fast as they could and charge you handsomely for the privilege you go running back to your hotel room you'd get your hand lens out you'd look
through all the negatives you'd pick the best pictures you'd put them in a federal express envelope and they'd be overnighted to your newspaper office if
you're lucky in time to make the back page of the Morning Edition or the front page if your country had won a gold
medal that day now Sydney was different for a whole bunch of reasons one it's a
long way away from I mean it's not a long way away from Sydney but it's a long way away from every else it's a long way from most of the rest of
Australia and I know because I was there in December the time zone is a massive Factor you cannot overnight FedEx
printed film and negatives from Sydney to New York to Washington to London to Paris but also 2000 internet had kind of
just got good enough to be usable now there's not a lot of success stories about Australian internet but this is
definitely one of them hotels had a business center that probably had like
dual line ISDN you could get 100 maybe 200 kilobits which was enough to send a couple of pictures back to your editor
but the third Factor was this thing this is the nickon D1 it wasn't the first digital camera that happened about 20

in 2004 people were like oh yeah old school Bros Still rocking it but this was the Tipping Point cuz the nickon D1
now this wasn't amazing it was like two .1 megapixel it had a tiny little viewfinder on the back but what the
press and the photographers realized really quickly is that the analog photos weren't getting used because the

one as far as photography is concerned and the beginning of digital now the

Now mp3 the audio format is older than anyone remembers because for about 5
years it wasn't useful for anything the format was created in 1991 but in 1991
there were no computers in the world fast enough to play an MP3 file because it took 15 minutes to decompress a
3-minute song so if you wanted to listen to mp3s first you needed a hard drive that could store them we didn't have

it for nerds brilliant for people working in it brilliant college students brilliant normal human beings no they

old school but this is the one that normal people wanted because it had style it was iconic it had these white

Steve Jobs had figured out the thing which triggered the Tipping Point for this was that the iPod wasn't just about
a device that played songs the iPod was part of an ecosystem that sold music now
the music industry the recording industry they thought they sold music they didn't they sold plastic they put
the music on discs and cassettes and they put the cassettes in boxes and Jewel cases and slip cases and they put
them on trucks and they drove them all over the world and they put them in the stores and when you went to buy a record what you would do is you'd go to town
and you'd choose a piece of plastic that you liked and you'd pay money for it and when you got it home you'd put it on a machine and it would make a noise but
the plastic was the thing you paid for our concept our understanding of ownership is so predicated in the day
when the music was indistinguishable from the physical packaging that it came on and it was Steve Jobs who sat the
record companies down and went look stop freaking out MP3 is not going to kill you what if what if you could sell the
songs without the plastic what if your customers would give you 99 Cents and we'll take 30% because we got to make
bank and you just give them the song you don't need to put anything in a truck you don't need to press anything you don't need to print anything your
manufacturing costs become zero and you can just sell the songs and that's what
triggered the revolution now the thing about the predecessors to this what happened in both of these scenarios is
that the cost of delivering something went effectively to zero the cost of
taking a photograph and then looking at it went from you know maybe a pound 50
whatever to effectively zero the cost of being able to acquire and listen to a song went to effectively zero obviously

eliminated this scarcity we eliminated these constraints now I was at an event
